problems.title: Find Maximum in Array
problems.description:
Write a program that reads an array of N integers and prints the largest element.

Input Format
First line contains N. Second line contains N space-separated integers:
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print a single integer — the maximum element.
```
max
```

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 5 3 9 2
```

Sample Output 1
```
9
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
-1 -5 -2
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```

Explanation
In Sample 1: Among {1,5,3,9,2}, the maximum is 9.
In Sample 2: Among {-1,-5,-2}, the maximum is -1 (least negative).
problems.hint: Initialize max to the first element, then loop and update if a larger element is found.
problems.explanation:
To find the maximum, scan every element and keep track of the largest one seen so far.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize max = arr[0] (assume first element is the largest).
2. Loop from index 1 to N-1:
   - If arr[i] > max, update max = arr[i].
3. Print max after the loop.

Trace for [1,5,3,9,2]:
max=1 → 5>1→max=5 → 3<5 → 9>5→max=9 → 2<9
Result: 9

problems.title: Array Sum
problems.description:
Write a program that reads an array of N integers and prints the sum of all elements.

Input Format
First line contains N. Second line contains N space-separated integers:
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print a single integer — the sum.
```
sum
```

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
4
1 2 3 4
```

Sample Output 1
```
10
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
5 5 10
```

Sample Output 2
```
20
```

Explanation
1+2+3+4 = 10
5+5+10 = 20
problems.hint: Initialize sum=0, add each element.
problems.explanation:
Sum all array elements using the accumulator pattern.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize sum = 0.
2. Loop through each element.
3. Add each element to sum.
4. Print sum after the loop.

This is the classic accumulator pattern — start at 0 and add each value.

Trace for [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]:
0+1=1, 1+2=3, 3+3=6, 6+4=10, 10+5=15
Result: 15

problems.title: Reverse Array
problems.description:
Write a program that reads an array of N integers and prints elements in reverse order, space-separated.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
```
aN ... a2 a1
```

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 3 4 5
```

Sample Output 1
```
5 4 3 2 1
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
10 20 30
```

Sample Output 2
```
30 20 10
```

Explanation
{1,2,3,4,5} reversed = {5,4,3,2,1}
problems.hint: Loop from index N-1 down to 0 and print each element.
problems.explanation:
To reverse an array, iterate from the last element to the first.

Step-by-step:
1. Loop from index i = N-1 down to 0.
2. Print arr[i].
3. Add a space after each element, except the last one.

This approach prints the elements in reverse order without modifying the original array.

Trace for [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]:
i=4: print 5
i=3: print 4
i=2: print 3
i=1: print 2
i=0: print 1
Result: 5 4 3 2 1

problems.title: Linear Search
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and a target X, then print the 0-based index of X if found, or -1 if not found.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
X
```

Output Format
Print the 0-based index or -1.
```
index
```

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i], X ≤ 10^6
• Print the first occurrence.

Sample Input 1
```
5
10 20 30 40 50
30
```

Sample Output 1
```
2
```

Sample Input 2
```
5
10 20 30 40 50
60
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```

Explanation
30 is at index 2. 60 is not in the array.
problems.hint: Loop through the array, compare each element to X. Return index on match, -1 if no match found.
problems.explanation:
Linear Search checks every element one by one until the target is found.

Step-by-step:
1. Loop through each index i from 0 to N-1.
2. If arr[i] equals the target, print i and stop.
3. If the loop finishes without a match, print -1.

Time complexity: O(n) — worst case checks every element.

Trace: arr=[10,30,20,50], target=20
- i=0: 10≠20
- i=1: 30≠20
- i=2: 20=20 → print 2, done

problems.title: Find Minimum Element
problems.description:
Write a program that reads an array of N integers and prints the smallest element.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
```
min
```

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 5 3 9 2
```

Sample Output 1
```
1
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
-1 -5 -2
```

Sample Output 2
```
-5
```

Explanation
In Sample 1: Among {1,5,3,9,2}, the minimum is 1.
In Sample 2: Among {-1,-5,-2}, the minimum is -5.
problems.hint: Initialize min to the first element, then loop and update if a smaller element is found.
problems.explanation:
To find the minimum, scan every element keeping track of the smallest seen so far.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize min = arr[0].
2. Loop from index 1 to N-1: if arr[i] < min, update min = arr[i].
3. Print min.

Trace for [1,5,3,9,2]:
min=1 → 5>1 → 3>1 → 9>1 → 2>1
Result: 1

problems.title: Average of Elements
problems.description:
Write a program that reads N integers and prints their average rounded to 2 decimal places.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the average with exactly 2 decimal places.
```
avg
```

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
4
1 2 3 4
```

Sample Output 1
```
2.50
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
10 20 30
```

Sample Output 2
```
20.00
```

Explanation
(1+2+3+4)/4 = 10/4 = 2.50
(10+20+30)/3 = 60/3 = 20.00
problems.hint: Compute sum of all elements, then divide by N. Use floating point division.
problems.explanation:
Average = sum of all elements / count.

Step-by-step:
1. Read all N elements and compute their sum.
2. Divide sum by N using float division.
3. Print the result with 2 decimal places.

Key point: In C, use (float)sum/n or sum*1.0/n to avoid integer division.
In Python, print(f'{avg:.2f}') formats to 2 decimal places.

Trace for [1,2,3,4]: sum=10, avg=10/4=2.50

problems.title: Count Occurrences
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and a target X. Print how many times X appears in the array.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
X
```

Output Format
Print a single integer — the count.
```
count
```

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i], X ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
1 2 3 2 2 4
2
```

Sample Output 1
```
3
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
5 6 7 8
9
```

Sample Output 2
```
0
```

Explanation
In Sample 1: 2 appears at indices 1, 3, 4 → count = 3.
In Sample 2: 9 is not in the array → count = 0.
problems.hint: Initialize count=0, loop through array, increment count whenever arr[i]==X.
problems.explanation:
Count occurrences by scanning the array and incrementing a counter on each match.

Step-by-step:
1. Read count = 0.
2. Loop through each element.
3. If arr[i] == X, count++.
4. Print count.

Trace for [1,2,3,2,2,4], X=2:
i=0: 1≠2 | i=1: 2=2, count=1 | i=2: 3≠2 | i=3: 2=2, count=2 | i=4: 2=2, count=3 | i=5: 4≠2
Result: 3

problems.title: Check Existence
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and a target X. Print YES if X exists in the array, NO otherwise.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
X
```

Output Format
Print YES or NO.

Sample Input 1
```
5
3 1 4 1 5
4
```

Sample Output 1
```
YES
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
10 20 30 40
99
```

Sample Output 2
```
NO
```

Explanation
4 is in the array → YES. 99 is not → NO.
problems.hint: Loop through the array. If arr[i]==X, print YES and stop. After loop, print NO.
problems.explanation:
Check membership by scanning each element.

Step-by-step:
1. Loop through array.
2. If arr[i] == X, print YES and exit.
3. If loop finishes without match, print NO.

In Python: simply check 'if X in arr'.
In C: use a flag variable found=0, set to 1 on match.

Trace for [3,1,4,1,5], X=4:
3≠4 | 1≠4 | 4=4 → print YES, stop.

problems.title: Find Second Largest Element
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and print the second largest distinct element. If no second largest exists, print -1.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the second largest element or -1.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
12 35 1 10 34 1
```

Sample Output 1
```
34
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
5 5 5
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```

Explanation
Sorted distinct: {1,10,12,34,35} → second largest = 34.
All same → no second distinct → -1.
problems.hint: Track two variables: first (largest) and second. Update carefully when iterating.
problems.explanation:
Track first and second largest in a single pass.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize first = second = -∞.
2. For each element x:
   - If x > first: second = first, first = x
   - Else if x > second AND x ≠ first: second = x
3. If second is still -∞, print -1. Else print second.

Trace for [12,35,1,10,34,1]:
first=12,sec=-∞ → first=35,sec=12 → 1<12 → 10<12 → 34>12,sec=34 → 1<34
Result: 34

problems.title: Find Second Smallest Element
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and print the second smallest distinct element. If no second smallest exists, print -1.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the second smallest element or -1.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
4 6 1 2 7
```

Sample Output 1
```
2
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
3 3 3 3
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```

Explanation
Distinct sorted: {1,2,4,6,7} → second smallest = 2.
All same → -1.
problems.hint: Track two variables: first (smallest) and second. Update when a smaller or second-smaller element is found.
problems.explanation:
Track first and second smallest in a single pass.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize first = second = +∞.
2. For each element x:
   - If x < first: second = first, first = x
   - Else if x < second AND x ≠ first: second = x
3. If second is still +∞, print -1. Else print second.

Trace for [4,6,1,2,7]:
first=4,sec=∞ → 6>4 → first=1,sec=4 → sec=2 → 7>2
Result: 2

problems.title: Merge Two Arrays
problems.description:
Read two arrays A (of size M) and B (of size N). Print all elements of A followed by all elements of B, space-separated on one line.

Input Format
```
M
a1 a2 ... aM
N
b1 b2 ... bN
```

Output Format
Print M+N space-separated integers.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ M, N ≤ 500
• −10^6 ≤ elements ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
3
1 2 3
3
4 5 6
```

Sample Output 1
```
1 2 3 4 5 6
```

Sample Input 2
```
2
10 20
3
5 6 7
```

Sample Output 2
```
10 20 5 6 7
```

Explanation
Simply concatenate A then B and print.
problems.hint: Store both arrays, then print elements of A followed by elements of B.
problems.explanation:
Merging two arrays means combining them in order.

Step-by-step:
1. Read array A of size M.
2. Read array B of size N.
3. Print all elements of A space-separated.
4. Continue printing elements of B space-separated.

In Python: merged = A + B; print(*merged)
In C: loop A then loop B, printing each with a space.

Note: Watch trailing spaces — print space before each element except the first, or use join.

problems.title: Remove Duplicates
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and print only the unique elements in their first-occurrence order, space-separated.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print unique elements preserving insertion order.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
7
1 2 3 2 1 4 3
```

Sample Output 1
```
1 2 3 4
```

Sample Input 2
```
5
5 5 5 5 5
```

Sample Output 2
```
5
```

Explanation
{1,2,3,2,1,4,3}: first occurrences in order → 1 2 3 4.
problems.hint: Use a boolean array or a set to track which elements have already been printed.
problems.explanation:
Use a visited marker to skip repeated elements.

Step-by-step:
1. Create a set (or boolean check array) 'seen'.
2. Loop through the array.
3. If arr[i] is not in 'seen', print it and add it to 'seen'.
4. If it is in 'seen', skip it.

In Python: use a dict/set for O(1) lookup.
In C: inner loop to check if element appeared before.

Trace [1,2,3,2,1,4,3]: 1→new, 2→new, 3→new, 2→seen, 1→seen, 4→new, 3→seen
Output: 1 2 3 4

problems.title: Find Missing Number
problems.description:
Given an array of N-1 integers in range [1, N] with no duplicates, find the missing number.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... a(N-1)
```

Output Format
Print the missing number.

Constraints
• 2 ≤ N ≤ 10000
• All values are distinct and in [1, N]
• Exactly one number is missing

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 4 5
```

Sample Output 1
```
3
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
1 3 4
```

Sample Output 2
```
2
```

Explanation
Expected sum for [1..5] = 15. Actual sum = 12. Missing = 15-12 = 3.
problems.hint: Use the formula: sum of 1..N = N*(N+1)/2. Subtract the actual array sum to get the missing number.
problems.explanation:
The sum formula trick gives O(1) solution.

Step-by-step:
1. Compute expected sum = N*(N+1)/2.
2. Compute actual sum of the array.
3. Missing = expected - actual.

Why it works: The array has all numbers from 1..N except one. The difference between the full sum and the actual sum is the missing number.

Trace: N=5, expected=15, arr=[1,2,4,5], actual=12, missing=3.

problems.title: Find Duplicate Number
problems.description:
Given an array of N integers where each value is in [1, N-1] and exactly one value appears twice, find the duplicate.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the duplicate number.

Constraints
• 2 ≤ N ≤ 10000
• All values in [1, N-1]
• Exactly one duplicate

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 3 4 2 2
```

Sample Output 1
```
2
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
3 1 3 4
```

Sample Output 2
```
3
```

Explanation
Actual sum − expected sum = duplicate (sum trick). Or: if arr[i] seen before, it is the duplicate.
problems.hint: Sum trick: duplicate = actual_sum - expected_sum (N*(N-1)/2). Or use a frequency array.
problems.explanation:
Use the sum approach: expected sum = 1+2+...+(N-1) = N*(N-1)/2.
Duplicate = actual_sum - expected_sum.

Alternatively, use a visited boolean array of size N.

Step-by-step (sum):
1. Compute actual = sum of all elements.
2. Compute expected = N*(N-1)/2.
3. Duplicate = actual - expected.

Trace: arr=[1,3,4,2,2], N=5
actual=12, expected=10, duplicate=2.

problems.title: Move Zeroes to End
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Move all zeroes to the end while maintaining the relative order of non-zero elements.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the rearranged array space-separated.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
8
0 1 0 3 12 0 5 0
```

Sample Output 1
```
1 3 12 5 0 0 0 0
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
1 2 3 4
```

Sample Output 2
```
1 2 3 4
```

Explanation
Non-zeros [1,3,12,5] keep their order, then four zeroes fill the rest.
problems.hint: Two-pass: first collect all non-zero elements, then append the required number of zeroes.
problems.explanation:
Two-pass approach:

Step-by-step:
1. Create result list: first pass — add all non-zero elements.
2. Count zeros = N - len(result).
3. Append that many zeros to result.
4. Print result.

Alternative (in-place): use two pointers. Left pointer tracks where next non-zero goes. Swap arr[left] with arr[right] when arr[right]!=0.

Trace [0,1,0,3,12,0,5,0]:
Non-zeros: [1,3,12,5]
Append 4 zeros → [1,3,12,5,0,0,0,0]

problems.title: Find Intersection of Two Arrays
problems.description:
Read two arrays A (of size M) and B (of size N). Print their intersection — elements that appear in both arrays — without duplicates, in sorted order.

Input Format
```
M
a1 a2 ... aM
N
b1 b2 ... bN
```

Output Format
Print intersection elements sorted and space-separated. Print -1 if intersection is empty.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ M, N ≤ 500
• −10^6 ≤ elements ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 3 4 5
5
3 4 5 6 7
```

Sample Output 1
```
3 4 5
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
1 2 3
3
4 5 6
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```

Explanation
{1,2,3,4,5} ∩ {3,4,5,6,7} = {3,4,5}.
problems.hint: Convert both arrays to sets, compute their intersection, sort and print.
problems.explanation:
Use set intersection for O(M+N) solution.

Step-by-step:
1. Convert A to a set setA.
2. For each element in B, check if it's in setA.
3. Collect matches in a result set (to avoid duplicates).
4. Sort result and print.
5. If result is empty, print -1.

In Python: result = sorted(set(A) & set(B))
In C: nested loops with duplicate checks.

Trace: A={1,2,3,4,5}, B={3,4,5,6,7}
Common: 3,4,5 → sorted: 3 4 5

problems.title: Find Union of Two Arrays
problems.description:
Read two arrays A (of size M) and B (of size N). Print their union — all distinct elements from both arrays — in sorted order.

Input Format
```
M
a1 a2 ... aM
N
b1 b2 ... bN
```

Output Format
Print union elements sorted and space-separated.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ M, N ≤ 500
• −10^6 ≤ elements ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 3 4 5
5
3 4 5 6 7
```

Sample Output 1
```
1 2 3 4 5 6 7
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
1 2 3
3
1 2 3
```

Sample Output 2
```
1 2 3
```

Explanation
Union = all unique elements from both sets.
problems.hint: Add all elements of A and B into a set, then sort and print.
problems.explanation:
Union combines all unique elements from both arrays.

Step-by-step:
1. Create a set and insert all elements from A.
2. Insert all elements from B.
3. Sort the set and print.

In Python: result = sorted(set(A) | set(B))
In C: merge both arrays, sort, then skip duplicates.

Trace: A={1,2,3,4,5}, B={3,4,5,6,7}
Union={1,2,3,4,5,6,7} → sorted: 1 2 3 4 5 6 7

problems.title: Find Pair with Given Sum
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and a target sum S. Print the first pair of indices (i, j) where i < j and arr[i] + arr[j] == S. Print -1 if no such pair exists.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
S
```

Output Format
Print two space-separated indices: i j. Or print -1.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i], S ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
2 7 4 1 11 6
9
```

Sample Output 1
```
0 1
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
1 2 3 4
10
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```

Explanation
arr[0]+arr[1] = 2+7 = 9 = S.
problems.hint: Use a nested loop: for each i, check all j > i. If arr[i]+arr[j]==S, print and exit.
problems.explanation:
Brute force O(N²): check all pairs.

Step-by-step:
1. Loop i from 0 to N-2.
2. Loop j from i+1 to N-1.
3. If arr[i]+arr[j] == S, print i and j, and stop.
4. After all loops, print -1.

Optimized: use a hash map — store (S - arr[i]) as you iterate.

Trace: arr=[2,7,4,1,11,6], S=9
i=0: need 7, check j=1: arr[1]=7 → match → print 0 1

problems.title: Rotate Array
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and rotate it to the right by K positions.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
K
```

Output Format
Print the rotated array space-separated.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• 0 ≤ K ≤ 10^6
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 3 4 5
2
```

Sample Output 1
```
4 5 1 2 3
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
10 20 30 40
1
```

Sample Output 2
```
40 10 20 30
```

Explanation
Right rotate by 2: last 2 elements move to front.
[1,2,3,4,5] → [4,5,1,2,3]
problems.hint: Use k = k % n to handle k > n. Then print arr[n-k .. n-1] then arr[0 .. n-k-1].
problems.explanation:
Right rotation by K means the last K elements come first.

Step-by-step:
1. Compute k = k % n (handles k > n).
2. Print elements from index (n-k) to (n-1).
3. Print elements from index 0 to (n-k-1).

In Python: rotated = arr[-k:] + arr[:-k] (if k > 0)

Trace: arr=[1,2,3,4,5], k=2 → k%5=2
Slice: arr[3..4]=[4,5] + arr[0..2]=[1,2,3]
Result: 4 5 1 2 3

problems.title: Find Majority Element
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Print the majority element — the element that appears more than N/2 times. Print -1 if no majority element exists.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the majority element or -1.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
7
3 3 4 2 3 3 1
```

Sample Output 1
```
3
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
1 2 3 4
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```

Explanation
3 appears 4 times in an array of size 7. 4 > 7/2 = 3.5 → majority.
In Sample 2: no element appears more than 2 times.
problems.hint: Count frequency of each element. If any element's count > N/2, it's the majority. Otherwise print -1.
problems.explanation:
Use a frequency map or the Boyer-Moore Voting Algorithm.

Frequency approach:
1. Count occurrences of each element using a map/dict.
2. If any count > N/2, print that element.
3. Otherwise print -1.

Boyer-Moore (O(n) space O(1)):
1. Maintain candidate and vote count.
2. For each element: if count==0, set candidate=element, count=1; else if element==candidate, count++; else count--.
3. Verify candidate by counting it in the array.

Trace [3,3,4,2,3,3,1]: freq of 3=4, 4 > 7/2=3.5 → print 3.

problems.title: Check if Array is Sorted
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Print YES if it is sorted in non-decreasing order, NO otherwise.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print YES or NO.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 3 4 5
```

Sample Output 1
```
YES
```

Sample Input 2
```
5
5 3 4 1 2
```

Sample Output 2
```
NO
```

Explanation
[1,2,3,4,5] is non-decreasing → YES.
[5,3,4,1,2] has 5>3 → not sorted → NO.
problems.hint: Loop from index 1 to N-1. If arr[i] < arr[i-1], print NO and stop. If loop completes, print YES.
problems.explanation:
Check adjacent pairs — if any pair is out of order, it's not sorted.

Step-by-step:
1. Loop from i=1 to N-1.
2. If arr[i] < arr[i-1], print NO and exit.
3. If loop completes without violation, print YES.

A single-element array is always sorted.

Trace [1,2,3,4,5]: 2>=1, 3>=2, 4>=3, 5>=4
All OK → YES

problems.title: Find Minimum in Rotated Sorted Array
problems.description:
A sorted array in ascending order was rotated at some unknown pivot. Find the minimum element.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the minimum element.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• All elements are distinct
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
4 5 6 7 0 1 2
```

Sample Output 1
```
0
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
3 1 2
```

Sample Output 2
```
1
```

Explanation
The array [1,2,4,5,6,7] was rotated to get [4,5,6,7,0,1,2]. Minimum is 0.
problems.hint: The minimum is where the sequence resets (arr[i] < arr[i-1]). Or simply scan for minimum.
problems.explanation:
The rotation point is where arr[i] < arr[i-1] — that's the minimum.

Simple O(N) approach:
1. Initialize min = arr[0].
2. Loop through array, update min if arr[i] < min.
3. Print min.

Binary Search O(log N):
1. If arr[mid] > arr[right], min is in right half.
2. Else min is in left half (including mid).
3. Continue until low==high.

Trace [4,5,6,7,0,1,2]:
Linear scan: min starts at 4, sees 0 < 4 → min=0
Result: 0

problems.title: Find Maximum Product of Two Elements
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Find and print the maximum product of any two distinct elements.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the maximum product.

Constraints
• 2 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 3 4 5
```

Sample Output 1
```
20
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
-10 -20 5 3
```

Sample Output 2
```
200
```

Explanation
Sample 1: 4*5=20 (two largest).
Sample 2: (-10)*(-20)=200 (two smallest/most negative give largest product).
problems.hint: Consider both: product of two largest and product of two most negative (smallest). Take the max.
problems.explanation:
Max product = max of (largest1 * largest2) and (smallest1 * smallest2).

Step-by-step:
1. Find the two largest elements (first, second max).
2. Find the two smallest elements (first, second min).
3. Answer = max(largest1 * largest2, smallest1 * smallest2).

Why both? Two negatives multiply to a large positive.

Trace: [-10,-20,5,3]
Two largest: 5,3 → 15
Two smallest: -20,-10 → 200
Answer: max(15,200) = 200

problems.title: Separate Even and Odd Numbers
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Print all even numbers first (in their original order), followed by all odd numbers (in their original order).

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the rearranged array space-separated.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• 0 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7
```

Sample Output 1
```
2 4 6 1 3 5 7
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
2 4 6 8
```

Sample Output 2
```
2 4 6 8
```

Explanation
Evens in order: 2,4,6 — Odds in order: 1,3,5,7 → Result: 2 4 6 1 3 5 7
problems.hint: Two passes: first print all elements where arr[i]%2==0, then all where arr[i]%2!=0.
problems.explanation:
Two-pass separation:

Step-by-step:
1. Loop through array, collect all even numbers.
2. Loop again, collect all odd numbers.
3. Print evens then odds, space-separated.

In Python: evens = [x for x in arr if x%2==0]; odds = [x for x in arr if x%2!=0]; print(*(evens+odds))

Trace [1,2,3,4,5,6,7]:
Evens: [2,4,6]
Odds: [1,3,5,7]
Output: 2 4 6 1 3 5 7

problems.title: Find Longest Increasing Subsequence
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Find the length of the Longest Increasing Subsequence (LIS) — a subsequence where each element is strictly greater than the previous.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the length of the LIS.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
8
10 9 2 5 3 7 101 18
```

Sample Output 1
```
4
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
4 3 2 1
```

Sample Output 2
```
1
```

Explanation
Sample 1: LIS = [2,3,7,101] or [2,5,7,101] → length 4.
Sample 2: All decreasing → any single element is LIS → length 1.
problems.hint: Use DP: dp[i] = length of LIS ending at index i. dp[i] = 1 + max(dp[j]) for all j<i where arr[j]<arr[i].
problems.explanation:
Classic DP problem.

Step-by-step:
1. Create dp[] of size N, initialize all to 1 (each element is LIS of length 1).
2. For each i from 1 to N-1:
   - For each j from 0 to i-1:
     - If arr[j] < arr[i]: dp[i] = max(dp[i], dp[j]+1)
3. Return max of dp[] array.

Time: O(N²), Space: O(N).

Trace [10,9,2,5,3,7,101,18]:
dp = [1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1]
i=3: arr[3]=5 > arr[2]=2 → dp[3]=dp[2]+1=2
i=5: arr[5]=7 > arr[2]=2,arr[3]=5,arr[4]=3 → dp[5]=3
i=6: arr[6]=101 > all → dp[6]=4
Result: max(dp)=4

problems.title: Find k-th Largest Element
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and an integer K. Print the K-th largest element (1-indexed, so K=1 is the maximum).

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
K
```

Output Format
Print the K-th largest element.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ K ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
3 2 1 5 6 4
2
```

Sample Output 1
```
5
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
1 2 3 4
1
```

Sample Output 2
```
4
```

Explanation
Sorted desc: [6,5,4,3,2,1]. K=2 → 5.
For Sample 2: largest is 4.
problems.hint: Sort the array in descending order, then return element at index K-1.
problems.explanation:
Sort in descending order and pick the K-th element.

Step-by-step:
1. Sort array in descending order.
2. Print arr[K-1].

Alternative: Use a min-heap of size K. Maintain K largest seen so far.

In Python: arr.sort(reverse=True); print(arr[k-1])
In C: sort desc, print arr[k-1].

Trace: [3,2,1,5,6,4], k=2
Sorted desc: [6,5,4,3,2,1]
K=2 → index 1 → 5

problems.title: Find the Frequency of Each Element
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Print each unique element and its frequency, sorted by element value in ascending order. Each pair on a new line: element frequency.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
For each unique element in sorted order:
```
element frequency
```

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
1 2 3 1 2 1
```

Sample Output 1
```
1 3
2 2
3 1
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
5 5 5
```

Sample Output 2
```
5 3
```

Explanation
1 appears 3 times, 2 appears 2 times, 3 appears once. Output sorted by element.
problems.hint: Use a dictionary to count frequencies, then sort by key and print each key-value pair.
problems.explanation:
Count with a hash map, then output sorted by key.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize an empty frequency map.
2. For each element, increment its count in the map.
3. Sort the keys.
4. Print each key followed by its count.

In Python:
from collections import Counter
freq = Counter(arr)
for k in sorted(freq): print(k, freq[k])

Trace [1,2,3,1,2,1]: {1:3, 2:2, 3:1}
Sorted keys: 1,2,3
Output: 1 3 / 2 2 / 3 1

problems.title: Find Common Elements in Three Arrays
problems.description:
Read three arrays A, B, C. Print all elements common to all three, without duplicates, in sorted order.

Input Format
```
M
a1 a2 ... aM
N
b1 b2 ... bN
P
c1 c2 ... cP
```

Output Format
Print common elements sorted and space-separated. Print -1 if none.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ M, N, P ≤ 500
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
1 5 10 20 40 80
5
6 7 20 80 100
4
3 4 15 20
```

Sample Output 1
```
20
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
1 2 3
3
4 5 6
3
7 8 9
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```
problems.hint: Convert A to a set. Check each element of B against setA. Then from results, check each against C.
problems.explanation:
Intersection of three sets:

Step-by-step:
1. Convert A to setA.
2. Compute setAB = elements in B that are also in setA.
3. From setAB, keep elements that are also in C.
4. Sort and print result.

In Python: result = sorted(set(A) & set(B) & set(C))

Trace: A={1,5,10,20,40,80}, B={6,7,20,80,100}, C={3,4,15,20}
A∩B = {20,80}
(A∩B)∩C = {20}
Result: 20

problems.title: Find First Repeating Element
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Find the first element that repeats in the array. If no element repeats, print -1.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the first repeating element or -1.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
7
10 5 3 4 3 5 6
```

Sample Output 1
```
5
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
1 2 3 4
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```

Explanation
In [10, 5, 3, 4, 3, 5, 6], 5 is the first element (index 1) that appears again later.
problems.hint: Use a hash map to store the first occurrence index. The answer is the element with the minimum recurring index.
problems.explanation:
To find the first repeating element, we want the one whose first occurrence is earliest among all elements that repeat.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize a map `firstOccur` to store `{value: firstIndex}`.
2. Initialize `minIndex = infinity`.
3. Loop through array:
   - If element is in `firstOccur`: `minIndex = min(minIndex, firstOccur[element])`.
   - Else: Add element to `firstOccur` with its current index.
4. If `minIndex` changed, return element at `minIndex`. Else -1.

Trace [10, 5, 3, 4, 3, 5, 6]:
- 10: firstOccur={10:0}
- 5: firstOccur={10:0, 5:1}
- 3: firstOccur={..., 3:2}
- 4: firstOccur={..., 4:3}
- 3: repeat! minIndex=min(inf, 2)=2
- 5: repeat! minIndex=min(2, 1)=1
- minIndex=1 → arr[1]=5

problems.title: Find First Non-Repeating Element
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Find the first element that does not repeat (appears only once). If all elements repeat, print -1.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the first non-repeating element or -1.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
9 4 9 6 7 4
```

Sample Output 1
```
6
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
1 1 1
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```

Explanation
In [9, 4, 9, 6, 7, 4], 9 repeats, 4 repeats. 6 is the first unique element.
problems.hint: Count the frequency of each element, then iterate through the array and return the first element with frequency 1.
problems.explanation:
Two-pass hashing approach:

Step-by-step:
1. Count frequency of all elements using a hash map.
2. Iterate through the array a second time.
3. For each element, check its count in the hash map.
4. Return the first element whose count is 1.
5. If no such element, return -1.

Trace [9, 4, 9, 6, 7, 4]:
Freq: {9:2, 4:2, 6:1, 7:1}
Second pass:
- 9: count 2 (skip)
- 4: count 2 (skip)
- 9: count 2 (skip)
- 6: count 1 (MATCH!)
Result: 6

problems.title: Find Subarray with Given Sum
problems.description:
Read an array of N positive integers and a target sum S. Find a continuous subarray that adds up to S. Print the 1-based start and end indices. If multiple exist, print the first one. If none, print -1.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
S
```

Output Format
Print two 1-based indices (start end). Or print -1.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• 1 ≤ S ≤ 10^7
• 0 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^5

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 3 7 5
12
```

Sample Output 1
```
2 4
```

Sample Input 2
```
5
1 2 3 4 5
100
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```

Explanation
In [1,2,3,7,5], subarray [2,3,7] sums to 12. 1-based indices are 2 and 4.
problems.hint: Use the sliding window (two pointers) technique. Maintain a window sum and move pointers carefully.
problems.explanation:
Since all numbers are non-negative, we can use a sliding window efficiently.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `start = 0`, `currentSum = 0`.
2. Loop `end` from 0 to N-1:
   - Add `arr[end]` to `currentSum`.
   - While `currentSum > S` and `start < end`:
     - Subtract `arr[start]` from `currentSum`, increment `start`.
   - If `currentSum == S`:
     - Print `start+1` and `end+1` and exit.
3. Print -1 if no window found.

Trace [1,2,3,7,5], S=12:
- end=0, sum=1
- end=1, sum=3
- end=2, sum=6
- end=3, sum=13. 13>12 → sum=13-1=12. Start is now index 1.
- sum=12 == S! Start=1, End=3 → index 2 4

problems.title: Find the Missing and Repeating Number
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers containing values from [1, N]. One value appears twice (repeating) and one value is missing. Print the repeating followed by the missing number.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
```
repeating missing
```

Constraints
• 2 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• All values in [1, N]

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 3 2 5
```

Sample Output 1
```
2 4
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
1 3 3
```

Sample Output 2
```
3 2
```

Explanation
In [1,2,3,2,5], 2 repeats and 4 is missing.
problems.hint: Use a frequency array to count occurrences. The element with count 2 is repeating, and the element with count 0 is missing.
problems.explanation:
Simple frequency array solution:

Step-by-step:
1. Create a frequency array `counts` of size N+1, initialized to 0.
2. For each element `x` in the input, `counts[x]++`.
3. Iterate `i` from 1 to N:
   - If `counts[i] == 2`, `repeating = i`.
   - If `counts[i] == 0`, `missing = i`.
4. Print `repeating` and `missing`.

Trace [1,2,3,2,5]:
Counts: {1:1, 2:2, 3:1, 4:0, 5:1}
repeating=2, missing=4

problems.title: Sort Array of 0s, 1s, and 2s
problems.description:
Read an array of size N containing only 0s, 1s, and 2s. Sort the array in ascending order without using library sort functions.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the sorted array space-separated.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• a[i] ∈ {0, 1, 2}

Sample Input 1
```
6
0 1 2 2 1 0
```

Sample Output 1
```
0 0 1 1 2 2
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
2 1 0
```

Sample Output 2
```
0 1 2
```

Explanation
The array contains only 0s, 1s, and 2s. Group them in order.
problems.hint: Dutch National Flag Algorithm: use three pointers (low, mid, high) to partition the array in a single pass.
problems.explanation:
Dutch National Flag (DNF) algorithm is the most efficient (O(N) time, O(1) space).

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `low = 0`, `mid = 0`, `high = N-1`.
2. While `mid <= high`:
   - If `arr[mid] == 0`: Swap `arr[low]` and `arr[mid]`, `low++`, `mid++`.
   - If `arr[mid] == 1`: `mid++`.
   - If `arr[mid] == 2`: Swap `arr[mid]` and `arr[high]`, `high--`.
3. Print the array.

Trace [0, 1, 2, 1, 0]:
low=0, mid=0, high=4 → mid=0: swap(0,0), low=1, mid=1
mid=1: 1, mid=2
mid=2: 2, swap(2,0), high=3
mid remains 2...
Result: [0, 0, 1, 1, 2]

problems.title: Find Leaders in Array
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. An element is a leader if it is greater than or equal to all the elements to its right. The rightmost element is always a leader. Print all leaders in order from right to left.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print leaders space-separated from right to left (as they appear in scanning).

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
16 17 4 3 5 2
```

Sample Output 1
```
2 5 17
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
1 2 3 4
```

Sample Output 2
```
4
```

Explanation
In [16, 17, 4, 3, 5, 2], from right scanning:
- 2 is rightmost → leader.
- 5 > 2 → leader.
- 3 < 5 → not leader.
- 4 < 5 → not leader.
- 17 > 5 → leader.
- 16 < 17 → not leader.
Output: 2 5 17
problems.hint: Scan from right to left and keep track of the maximum seen so far. If a new element is >= max, it's a leader.
problems.explanation:
To find leaders efficiently, scan from the end.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `maxSoFar = -infinity`.
2. Iterate through the array from `N-1` down to 0:
   - If `arr[i] >= maxSoFar`:
     - `arr[i]` is a leader. Print it.
     - Update `maxSoFar = arr[i]`.

Trace [16, 17, 4, 3, 5, 2]:
- i=5, val=2. 2 > -inf. Leader: 2, max=2
- i=4, val=5. 5 > 2. Leader: 5, max=5
- i=3, val=3. 3 < 5.
- i=2, val=4. 4 < 5.
- i=1, val=17. 17 > 5. Leader: 17, max=17
- i=0, val=16. 16 < 17.
Result: 2 5 17

problems.title: Find Equilibrium Index
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. An equilibrium index is an index i such that the sum of elements at lower indices is equal to the sum of elements at higher indices. Print the first equilibrium index (0-indexed) or -1 if none exist.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the index or -1.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5
• −10^4 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^4

Sample Input 1
```
7
-7 1 5 2 -4 3 0
```

Sample Output 1
```
3
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
1 2 3
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```

Explanation
In [-7, 1, 5, 2, -4, 3, 0], at index 3:
- Left sum: -7 + 1 + 5 = -1
- Right sum: -4 + 3 + 0 = -1
Indices are equal → result 3.
problems.hint: Calculate total sum first. Then iterate through the array, maintaining a left sum. Right sum = totalSum - leftSum - arr[i].
problems.explanation:
O(N) approach using total sum.

Step-by-step:
1. Compute `totalSum` of the array.
2. Initialize `leftSum = 0`.
3. Iterate through each index `i`:
   - `rightSum = totalSum - leftSum - arr[i]`.
   - If `leftSum == rightSum`, return `i`.
   - Update `leftSum += arr[i]`.
4. Return -1 if no index found.

Trace [-7, 1, 5, 2, -4, 3, 0]:
totalSum = 0.
i=0: left=0, right=0-0-(-7)=7. 0!=7. left=-7
i=1: left=-7, right=0-(-7)-1=6. -7!=6. left=-6
i=2: left=-6, right=0-(-6)-5=1. -6!=1. left=-1
i=3: left=-1, right=0-(-1)-2=-1. -1==-1! MATCH.
Result: 3

problems.title: Largest Sum Contiguous Subarray
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Find and print the sum of the contiguous subarray with the largest sum (Kadane's Algorithm).

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the maximum sum.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5
• −10^4 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^4

Sample Input 1
```
8
-2 -3 4 -1 -2 1 5 -3
```

Sample Output 1
```
7
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
-1 -2 -3 -4
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```

Explanation
In Sample 1, the subarray [4, -1, -2, 1, 5] has the maximum sum 7.
In Sample 2, the largest single element is -1.
problems.hint: Keep track of the maximum sum ending at the current position. Update the overall maximum sum whenever the current ending sum is greater.
problems.explanation:
Kadane's Algorithm O(N):

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `maxSoFar = arr[0]` and `currentMax = arr[0]`.
2. Iterate through the array starting from index 1:
   - `currentMax = max(arr[i], currentMax + arr[i])`
   - `maxSoFar = max(maxSoFar, currentMax)`
3. Print `maxSoFar`.

Trace [-2, -3, 4, -1, -2, 1, 5, -3]:
- -2: current=-2, max=-2
- -3: current=max(-3, -5)=-3, max=-2
- 4: current=max(4, 1)=4, max=4
- -1: current=max(-1, 3)=3, max=4
- -2: current=max(-2, 1)=1, max=4
- 1: current=max(1, 2)=2, max=4
- 5: current=max(5, 7)=7, max=7
- -3: current=max(-3, 4)=4, max=7
Result: 7

problems.title: Implement Binary Search
problems.description:
Read a sorted array of N integers and a target K. Find the index where K is located using the binary search algorithm. Print the index (0-indexed) or -1 if not found.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
K
```

Output Format
Print the index or -1.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5
• Array is sorted in ascending order
• −10^9 ≤ a[i], K ≤ 10^9

Sample Input 1
```
6
1 3 5 7 9 11
7
```

Sample Output 1
```
3
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
1 2 3 4
5
```

Sample Output 2
```
-1
```

Explanation
In [1,3,5,7,9,11], target 7 is at index 3.
problems.hint: Maintain low and high pointers. Compare target with mid element and discard half the search space in each step.
problems.explanation:
Binary Search Algorithm O(log N):

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `low = 0`, `high = N-1`.
2. While `low <= high`:
   - `mid = low + (high - low) / 2` (to avoid overflow).
   - If `arr[mid] == K`, return `mid`.
   - If `arr[mid] < K`, search right half: `low = mid + 1`.
   - If `arr[mid] > K`, search left half: `high = mid - 1`.
3. Return -1 if loop finished without finding K.

Trace [1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11], K=7:
- low=0, high=5, mid=2, val=5. 5 < 7 → low=3
- low=3, high=5, mid=4, val=9. 9 > 7 → high=3
- low=3, high=3, mid=3, val=7. 7 == 7 → return 3.

problems.title: Left Rotate Array by One
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Shift all elements to the left by one position and move the first element to the last position.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the rotated array space-separated.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 3 4 5
```

Sample Output 1
```
2 3 4 5 1
```

Sample Input 2
```
1
42
```

Sample Output 2
```
42
```

Explanation
In [1,2,3,4,5], shifting left by one gives [2,3,4,5] and then adding the first element 1 at the end gives [2,3,4,5,1].
problems.hint: Store the first element, shift all other elements to the left, and then place the first element at the last position.
problems.explanation:
Basic left rotation logic.

Step-by-step:
1. Store the first element `temp = arr[0]`.
2. Iterate through indices `i` from 0 to `N-2`:
   - `arr[i] = arr[i+1]`
3. Set `arr[N-1] = temp`.
4. Print result.

Trace [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]:
temp = 1
arr[0]=2, arr[1]=3, arr[2]=4, arr[3]=5
arr[4]=1
Result: 2 3 4 5 1

problems.title: Right Rotate Array by One
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Shift all elements to the right by one position and move the last element to the first position.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the rotated array space-separated.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 3 4 5
```

Sample Output 1
```
5 1 2 3 4
```

Sample Input 2
```
1
42
```

Sample Output 2
```
42
```

Explanation
In [1,2,3,4,5], the last element 5 is moved to index 0, and others shift right.
Result: [5,1,2,3,4].
problems.hint: Store the last element, shift all other elements to the right starting from the end, and then place the last element at the first position.
problems.explanation:
Basic right rotation logic.

Step-by-step:
1. Store the last element `temp = arr[N-1]`.
2. Iterate through indices `i` from `N-1` down to 1:
   - `arr[i] = arr[i-1]`
3. Set `arr[0] = temp`.
4. Print result.

Trace [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]:
temp = 5
arr[4]=4, arr[3]=3, arr[2]=2, arr[1]=1
arr[0]=5
Result: 5 1 2 3 4

problems.title: Find Pair with Given Product
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and a target product P. Find if there exists a pair of elements (a, b) such that a * b = P. Print "Yes" or "No".

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
P
```

Output Format
Print "Yes" or "No".

Constraints
• 2 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6
• −10^9 ≤ P ≤ 10^9

Sample Input 1
```
5
10 20 9 40 30
400
```

Sample Output 1
```
Yes
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
1 2 3 4
20
```

Sample Output 2
```
No
```

Explanation
In [10, 20, 9, 40, 30], 10 * 40 = 400. So Yes.
problems.hint: Use a hash set to store elements you've seen. For each element X, check if P is divisible by X and if P/X is in the set.
problems.explanation:
Hash set approach for O(N) time.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize an empty set `seen`.
2. Iterate through each element `x` in the array:
   - If `x` is 0:
     - If `P` is 0, return "Yes".
   - Else if `P % x == 0`:
     - If `P / x` is in `seen`, return "Yes".
   - Add `x` to `seen`.
3. Return "No".

Trace [10, 20, 9, 40, 30], P=400:
- 10: seen={10}
- 20: 400/20=20. 20 not in {10}. seen={10, 20}
- 9: 400%9 != 0. seen={10, 20, 9}
- 40: 400/40=10. 10 is in {10, 20, 9}! MATCH.
Result: Yes

problems.title: Check if Array is Palindrome
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Check if the array is a palindrome (reads the same forwards and backwards). Print "Yes" or "No".

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print "Yes" or "No".

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 3 2 1
```

Sample Output 1
```
Yes
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
1 2 3 4
```

Sample Output 2
```
No
```

Explanation
[1, 2, 3, 2, 1] reversed is [1, 2, 3, 2, 1]. So Yes.
problems.hint: Use two pointers, one at the beginning and one at the end. Move them towards Each other and check if elements are equal.
problems.explanation:
Two-pointer approach for Palindrome check.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `left = 0`, `right = N-1`.
2. While `left < right`:
   - If `arr[left] != arr[right]`, return "No".
   - Increment `left`, decrement `right`.
3. Return "Yes".

Trace [1, 2, 3, 2, 1]:
- left=0 (1), right=4 (1). Match.
- left=1 (2), right=3 (2). Match.
- left=right=2. Stop.
Result: Yes

problems.title: Print All Unique Elements
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Print all elements that appear only once in the array, in the same order as they first appear.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print space-separated unique elements.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
1 2 3 1 2 4
```

Sample Output 1
```
3 4
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
1 1 2 2
```

Sample Output 2

(Empty output if no unique elements)

Explanation
In [1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 4], 1 and 2 repeat. 3 and 4 appear once. Result: 3 4.
problems.hint: Use a frequency map to count occurrences. Then iterate through the array and print elements with count 1.
problems.explanation:
Two-pass hashing approach.

Step-by-step:
1. Create a frequency map to store counts of each element.
2. Iterate through the array:
   - Check the frequency of `arr[i]` in the map.
   - If count is 1, print `arr[i]`.

Trace [1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 4]:
Freq: {1:2, 2:2, 3:1, 4:1}
Iteration:
- 1: count 2 (skip)
- 2: count 2 (skip)
- 3: count 1 (Print: 3)
- 1: count 2 (skip)
- 2: count 2 (skip)
- 4: count 1 (Print: 4)
Result: 3 4

problems.title: Print All Duplicate Elements
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Print all elements that appear more than once in the array, once for each duplicate group, in the order of their first duplicate occurrence.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print space-separated duplicate elements.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
1 2 3 1 2 4
```

Sample Output 1
```
1 2
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
1 2 3
```

Sample Output 2

(Empty output if no duplicates exist)

Explanation
In [1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 4], 1 repeats and 2 repeats. 3 and 4 are unique.
problems.hint: Use a frequency map. Then filter and print elements that have a count > 1. Use a temporary set to ensure each duplicate element is printed only once.
problems.explanation:
Hashing approach with a second set to avoid repeating output.

Step-by-step:
1. Count frequency of all elements into a map.
2. Initialize an empty set `printed`.
3. Iterate through array:
   - If count of `arr[i]` > 1 and `arr[i]` not in `printed`:
     - Print `arr[i]`.
     - Add `arr[i]` to `printed`.

Trace [1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 4]:
Freq: {1:2, 2:2, 3:1, 4:1}
Iteration:
- 1: count 2, not printed. Print 1, printed={1}
- 2: count 2, not printed. Print 2, printed={1, 2}
- 3: count 1 (skip)
- 1: already in printed (skip)
- 2: already in printed (skip)
- 4: count 1 (skip)
Result: 1 2

problems.title: Merge Two Sorted Arrays
problems.description:
Read two sorted arrays A and B. Merge them into a single sorted array without using library sort functions.

Input Format
```
M
a1 a2 ... aM
N
b1 b2 ... bN
```

Output Format
Print the merged sorted array.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ M, N ≤ 5000
• Arrays are sorted
• −10^6 ≤ a[i], b[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
3
1 3 5
2
2 4
```

Sample Output 1
```
1 2 3 4 5
```

Sample Input 2
```
2
10 20
2
5 8
```

Sample Output 2
```
5 8 10 20
```

Explanation
1,3,5 and 2,4 merged into sorted order: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.
problems.hint: Use two pointers, one for each array. Compare elements at the pointers, append the smaller one to the result, and move that pointer forward.
problems.explanation:
Two-pointer merge technique (similar to Merge Sort merge step).

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `i = 0` (for A), `j = 0` (for B).
2. While `i < M` and `j < N`:
   - If `A[i] < B[j]`, print `A[i]`, `i++`.
   - Else, print `B[j]`, `j++`.
3. While `i < M`, print `A[i]`, `i++`.
4. While `j < N`, print `B[j]`, `j++`.

Trace [1, 3, 5], [2, 4]:
- 1 < 2? Yes. Print 1, i=1
- 3 < 2? No. Print 2, j=1
- 3 < 4? Yes. Print 3, i=2
- 5 < 4? No. Print 4, j=2 (B exhausted)
- Print remaining A: 5
Result: 1 2 3 4 5

problems.title: Rotate Array Right by K
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and a number K. Rotate the array to the right by K positions. If K > N, use K % N.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
K
```

Output Format
Print the rotated array space-separated.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• 0 ≤ K ≤ 10^5
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 3 4 5
2
```

Sample Output 1
```
4 5 1 2 3
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
10 20 30 40
1
```

Sample Output 2
```
40 10 20 30
```

Explanation
In [1,2,3,4,5], rotating right by 2:
- Rotate 1: [5, 1, 2, 3, 4]
- Rotate 2: [4, 5, 1, 2, 3].
problems.hint: The Reversal Algorithm: 1. Reverse the whole array. 2. Reverse the first K elements. 3. Reverse the remaining N-K elements.
problems.explanation:
Efficient O(N) rotation using reversal algorithm.

Step-by-step:
1. `K = K % N`.
2. Reverse the entire array.
3. Reverse the first `K` elements (indices `0` to `K-1`).
4. Reverse the rest of the elements (indices `K` to `N-1`).

Trace [1, 2, 3, 4, 5], K=2:
1. Reverse all: [5, 4, 3, 2, 1]
2. Reverse first 2: [4, 5, 3, 2, 1]
3. Reverse last 3: [4, 5, 1, 2, 3]
Result: 4 5 1 2 3

problems.title: Find Range of Array
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Calculate the range of the array. Range is the difference between the maximum and minimum elements of the array.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the range.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
10 2 3 8 5
```

Sample Output 1
```
8
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
1 2 3 4
```

Sample Output 2
```
3
```

Explanation
Sample 1: Max = 10, Min = 2. Range = 10 - 2 = 8.
Sample 2: Max = 4, Min = 1. Range = 4 - 1 = 3.
problems.hint: Find the maximum and minimum elements in a single pass. Then subtract min from max.
problems.explanation:
Max/Min tracking and subtraction.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `minVal = arr[0]`, `maxVal = arr[0]`.
2. Iterate through the array starting from index 1:
   - Update `minVal = min(minVal, arr[i])`.
   - Update `maxVal = max(maxVal, arr[i])`.
3. Result = `maxVal - minVal`.

Trace [10, 2, 3, 8, 5]:
min=2, max=10. Range = 10 - 2 = 8.

problems.title: Smallest Subarray with Sum Greater Than X
problems.description:
Read an array of N positive integers and a value X. Find the length of the smallest continuous subarray with sum greater than X. If no such subarray exists, print 0.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
X
```

Output Format
Print the length of the smallest subarray.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• 1 ≤ a[i], X ≤ 10^9

Sample Input 1
```
6
1 4 45 6 0 19
51
```

Sample Output 1
```
3
```

Sample Input 2
```
5
1 10 5 -2 7
9
```

Sample Output 2
```
1
```

Explanation
Sample 1: Subarray [44, 6, 0, 19] is not it. Subarray [45, 6, 19] sums to 70 > 51. Length 3.
Sample 2: Element 10 > 9. SMallest length is 1.
problems.hint: Use two pointers. Maintain a window sum. While the sum is greater than X, try to shrink the window from the left to find a smaller length.
problems.explanation:
Sliding window O(N) solution.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `start = 0`, `currentSum = 0`, `minLength = N + 1`.
2. Iterate `end` from 0 to N-1:
   - Add `arr[end]` to `currentSum`.
   - While `currentSum > X`:
     - Update `minLength = min(minLength, end - start + 1)`.
     - Subtract `arr[start]` from `currentSum` and increment `start`.
3. Return `minLength` if it was updated, otherwise 0.

Trace [1, 4, 45, 6, 0, 19], X=51:
- end=0..1: sum=5
- end=2: sum=50 < 51
- end=3: sum=56 > 51. minLen=4. start=1, sum=55. minLen=3. start=2, sum=51. not > 51.
- end=4: sum=51.
- end=5: sum=70 > 51. minLen=min(3, 5-2+1)=3. start=3, sum=25.
Result: 3

problems.title: Longest Subarray with Sum K
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers (including negative numbers) and a value K. Find the length of the longest continuous subarray that adds up to K. Print 0 if no such subarray exists.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
K
```

Output Format
Print the maximum length.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• −10^6 ≤ a[i], K ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
10 5 2 7 1 9
15
```

Sample Output 1
```
4
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
-1 2 3
6
```

Sample Output 2
```
0
```

Explanation
In [10, 5, 2, 7, 1, 9], subarray [5, 2, 7, 1] sums to 15. Length 4.
problems.hint: Use a hash map to store the first occurrence of each prefix sum. For each current prefix sum S, check if S-K exists in the map.
problems.explanation:
Prefix Sum + Hashing O(N) solution.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `prefixSum = 0`, `maxLen = 0`, and a map `map = {0: -1}`.
2. Iterate through array at index `i`:
   - `prefixSum += arr[i]`.
   - If `prefixSum - K` is in `map`:
     - `maxLen = max(maxLen, i - map[prefixSum - K])`.
   - If `prefixSum` is NOT in `map`, add it: `map[prefixSum] = i`.
3. Return `maxLen`.

Trace [10, 5, 2, 7, 1, 9], K=15:
- i=0, pSum=10. map={0:-1, 10:0}
- i=1, pSum=15. 15-15=0 in map? Yes. len=1-(-1)=2. map={..., 15:1}
- i=2, pSum=17. map={..., 17:2}
- i=3, pSum=24. 24-15=9 not in map. map={..., 24:3}
- i=4, pSum=25. 25-15=10 in map? Yes. len=4-0=4. maxLen=4.
... Result: 4

problems.title: Maximum Product Subarray
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Find and print the maximum product of a contiguous subarray.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the maximum product.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 2 * 10^4
• −10 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10

Sample Input 1
```
4
2 3 -2 4
```

Sample Output 1
```
6
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
-2 0 -1
```

Sample Output 2
```
0
```

Explanation
Sample 1: Subarray [2, 3] yields product 6.
Sample 2: Subarray [0] is the max product 0.
problems.hint: Since there can be negative numbers, maintain both current maximum and current minimum products ending at each position.
problems.explanation:
Dynamic Programming O(N) approach.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `res = arr[0]`, `currMax = arr[0]`, `currMin = arr[0]`.
2. Iterate through array from index 1:
   - If `arr[i] < 0`, swap `currMax` and `currMin`.
   - `currMax = max(arr[i], currMax * arr[i])`.
   - `currMin = min(arr[i], currMin * arr[i])`.
   - `res = max(res, currMax)`.
3. Return `res`.

Trace [2, 3, -2, 4]:
- 2: res=2, max=2, min=2
- 3: max=max(3, 6)=6, min=min(3, 6)=3. res=6
- -2: swap(6,3) → max=3, min=6. max=max(-2, -12)=-2, min=min(-2, -12)=-12. res=6
- 4: max=max(4, -8)=4, min=min(4, -48)=-48. res=6
Result: 6

problems.title: Count Subarrays with Given XOR
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and a value M. Count the total number of contiguous subarrays whose bitwise XOR sum is equal to M.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
M
```

Output Format
Print the total count.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 2 * 10^4
• 0 ≤ a[i], M ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
4 2 2 6 4
6
```

Sample Output 1
```
4
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
5 6 7 8
10
```

Sample Output 2
```
0
```

Explanation
In [4, 2, 2, 6, 4], target XOR 6:
Subarrays: [4,2], [4,2,2,6], [2,2,6], [6]. Total 4.
problems.hint: Use the property: if XOR(0..i) ^ XOR(0..j) = M, then XOR(i+1..j) = M. This can be rewritten as XOR(0..i) ^ M = XOR(0..j).
problems.explanation:
Prefix XOR + Hashing O(N) solution.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `xorSum = 0`, `count = 0`, and a map `map = {0: 1}`.
2. Iterate through array at index `i`:
   - `xorSum ^= arr[i]`.
   - `target = xorSum ^ M`.
   - If `target` is in `map`:
     - `count += map[target]`.
   - Update `map[xorSum] = map[xorSum] + 1` (or 1 if not exists).
3. Return `count`.

Trace [4, 2, 2, 6, 4], M=6:
- map={0:1}, xorSum=0, count=0
- val=4: xorSum=4. target=4^6=2. count=0. map={0:1, 4:1}
- val=2: xorSum=6. target=6^6=0. count=1. map={0:1, 4:1, 6:1}
- val=2: xorSum=4. target=4^6=2. count=1. map={0:1, 4:2, 6:1}
- val=6: xorSum=2. target=2^6=4. count=1+2=3. map={0:1, 4:2, 6:1, 2:1}
- val=4: xorSum=6. target=6^6=0. count=3+1=4. map={...}
Result: 4

problems.title: Rotate Matrix by 90 Degrees
problems.description:
Read an N x N 2D matrix. Rotate the matrix by 90 degrees clockwise in-place (if possible) or by creating a new matrix. Print the resulting matrix row by row.

Input Format
```
N
r1_c1 r1_c2 ... r1_cN
r2_c1 r2_c2 ... r2_cN
...
rN_c1 rN_c2 ... rN_cN
```

Output Format
Print N rows, each with N space-separated integers.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 100
• −10^4 ≤ matrix[i][j] ≤ 10^4

Sample Input 1
```
3
1 2 3
4 5 6
7 8 9
```

Sample Output 1
```
7 4 1
8 5 2
9 6 3
```

Sample Input 2
```
2
1 2
3 4
```

Sample Output 2
```
3 1
4 2
```

Explanation
Rotate Sample 1 clockwise:
1 2 3    7 4 1
4 5 6 -> 8 5 2
7 8 9    9 6 3
problems.hint: Method 1: Transpose the matrix and then reverse each row. Method 2: Create a new matrix where result[j][n-1-i] = original[i][j].
problems.explanation:
Standard 90-degree rotation algorithm.

Step-by-step (Transpose then Reverse):
1. Transpose the matrix: Swap `matrix[i][j]` with `matrix[j][i]` for all `i < j`.
2. Reverse each row: For each row `i`, swap `matrix[i][j]` with `matrix[i][N-1-j]` for `j < N/2`.

Trace Sample 1:
Original: [[1,2,3], [4,5,6], [7,8,9]]
Transpose: [[1,4,7], [2,5,8], [3,6,9]]
Reverse Rows: [[7,4,1], [8,5,2], [9,6,3]]
Result: 7 4 1 / 8 5 2 / 9 6 3

problems.title: Spiral Matrix Traversal
problems.description:
Read an M x N matrix. Traverse the matrix in spiral order (starting from the top-left element, moving right, then down, then left, then up, and repeating). Print the elements space-separated.

Input Format
```
M N
r1_c1 r1_c2 ... r1_cN
r2_c1 r2_c2 ... r2_cN
...
rM_c1 rM_c2 ... rM_cN
```

Output Format
Print space-separated integers in spiral order.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ M, N ≤ 100
• −10^4 ≤ matrix[i][j] ≤ 10^4

Sample Input 1
```
3 3
1 2 3
4 5 6
7 8 9
```

Sample Output 1
```
1 2 3 6 9 8 7 4 5
```

Sample Input 2
```
2 3
1 2 3
4 5 6
```

Sample Output 2
```
1 2 3 6 5 4
```

Explanation
Sample 1: Start (0,0) -> 1, 2, 3 (right), 6, 9 (down), 8, 7 (left), 4 (up), 5 (right).
problems.hint: Maintain four boundaries: top, bottom, left, right. Move across each boundary and shrink it until the boundaries overlap.
problems.explanation:
Standard Spiral Traversal Algorithm.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `top=0`, `bottom=M-1`, `left=0`, `right=N-1`.
2. While `top <= bottom` and `left <= right`:
   - Print top row: `left` to `right`. `top++`.
   - Print right col: `top` to `bottom`. `right--`.
   - If `top <= bottom`, print bottom row: `right` to `left`. `bottom--`.
   - If `left <= right`, print left col: `bottom` to `top`. `left++`.

Trace Sample 1 (3x3):
- TopRow: 1 2 3. top=1
- RightCol: 6 9. right=1
- BottomRow: 8 7. bottom=1
- LeftCol: 4. left=1
- TopRow: 5. top=2
Done.

problems.title: Set Matrix Zeroes
problems.description:
Read an M x N matrix. If an element is 0, set its entire row and column to 0. Do this in-place or logically to ensure it doesn't affect subsequent checks.

Input Format
```
M N
r1_c1 r1_c2 ... r1_cN
r2_c1 r2_c2 ... r2_cN
...
rM_c1 rM_c2 ... rM_cN
```

Output Format
Print the modified matrix row by row.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ M, N ≤ 100
• −10^6 ≤ matrix[i][j] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
3 3
1 1 1
1 0 1
1 1 1
```

Sample Output 1
```
1 0 1
0 0 0
1 0 1
```

Sample Input 2
```
3 3
0 1 2
3 4 5
1 3 1
```

Sample Output 2
```
0 0 0
0 4 5
0 3 1
```

Explanation
Sample 1: mat[1][1] is 0. So Row 1 and Col 1 become all 0s.
problems.hint: Use the first row and first column of the matrix itself to store whether a specific row or column needs to be zeroed.
problems.explanation:
Efficient In-place Matrix modification.

Step-by-step:
1. Check if first row and first column have any zeros.
2. Use result[0][0]... and result[...][0] to mark zeros for rows and cols.
3. Iterate from 1,1 to M,N. If `matrix[i][j] == 0`, set `matrix[i][0] = 0` and `matrix[0][j] = 0`.
4. Iterate again from 1,1 and set `matrix[i][j] = 0` if its row or col marker is 0.
5. Finally, zero the first row/col if needed based on markers from Step 1.

Trace Sample 2:
Initial: [[0,1,2], [3,4,5], [1,3,1]]
- Row 0 has a zero. Col 0 has a zero.
- Iterate through others... none.
- col 0 marker says Row 0 needs zeros. row 0 marker says Col 0 needs zeros.
Result: [[0,0,0], [0,4,5], [0,3,1]]

problems.title: Next Permutation
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Rearrange the numbers into the lexicographically next greater permutation of numbers. If no such arrangement exists, it must be rearranged as the lowest possible order (sorted in ascending order). Change the array in-place and print it.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print space-separated next permutation integers.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^4
• 0 ≤ a[i] ≤ 100

Sample Input 1
```
3
1 2 3
```

Sample Output 1
```
1 3 2
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
3 2 1
```

Sample Output 2
```
1 2 3
```

Explanation
Next permutation of [1, 2, 3] is [1, 3, 2].
Next permutation of [3, 2, 1] is the lowest possible [1, 2, 3].
problems.hint: 1. Find the first decreasing element from the right. 2. Find the slightly larger element to its right. 3. Swap them. 4. Reverse the tail.
problems.explanation:
Next Permutation O(N) Algorithm.

Step-by-step:
1. Find the largest index `k` such that `arr[k] < arr[k+1]`. If no such index exists, reverse the whole array and return.
2. Find the largest index `l` greater than `k` such that `arr[k] < arr[l]`.
3. Swap `arr[k]` and `arr[l]`.
4. Reverse the sequence from `arr[k+1]` up to the end of the array.

Trace [1, 5, 8, 4, 7, 6, 5, 3, 1]:
- k = 3 (val 4, because 4 < 7)
- l = 6 (val 5, because 5 is smallest val > 4 to its right)
- Swap 4 and 5: [1, 5, 8, 5, 7, 6, 4, 3, 1]
- Reverse from k+1 (index 4) to end: [1, 5, 8, 5, 1, 3, 4, 6, 7]
Result: next lexicographical permutation.

problems.title: 3Sum Problem
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and a target sum K. Find if there exist three elements in the array such that their sum is exactly K. Print "Yes" or "No".

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
K
```

Output Format
Print "Yes" or "No".

Constraints
• 3 ≤ N ≤ 2000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i], K ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
12 3 4 1 6 9
24
```

Sample Output 1
```
Yes
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
1 2 3 4
20
```

Sample Output 2
```
No
```

Explanation
In [12, 3, 4, 1, 6, 9], the triplet [12, 6, 6] doesn't work (unique elements needed if not specified, but problem asks for 3 elements). Triplet (12, 3, 9) sums to 24. So Yes.
problems.hint: Sort the array. Then for each element `i`, use the two-pointer approach for the remaining part to find two elements that sum to `K - arr[i]`.
problems.explanation:
Sorted Two-Pointer O(N^2) solution.

Step-by-step:
1. Sort the array.
2. Iterate `i` from 0 to N-3:
   - Let `target = K - arr[i]`.
   - Initialize `left = i + 1`, `right = N - 1`.
   - While `left < right`:
     - `sum = arr[left] + arr[right]`.
     - If `sum == target`, return "Yes".
     - If `sum < target`, `left++`.
     - Else `right--`.
3. Return "No".

Trace Sample 1: Sorted [1, 3, 4, 6, 9, 12], K=24
- i=0 (1), target=23. left=1(3), right=5(12). sum=15 < 23. ...
- i=1 (3), target=21. left=2(4), right=5(12). sum=16 < 21.
- i=2 (4), target=20. left=3(6), right=5(12). sum=18 < 20.
- i=3 (6), target=18. left=4(9), right=5(12). sum=21 > 18. left=5... stop.
- Wait, (12, 3, 9) = 24. My trace missed it.
i=1 (3), target=21. left=5 is 12. 12+9=21! YES.

problems.title: 4Sum Problem
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and a target sum K. Find if there exist four elements in the array such that their sum is exactly K. Print "Yes" or "No".

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
K
```

Output Format
Print "Yes" or "No".

Constraints
• 4 ≤ N ≤ 500
• −10^6 ≤ a[i], K ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
10 2 3 4 5 7
23
```

Sample Output 1
```
Yes
```

Sample Input 2
```
5
1 2 3 4 5
100
```

Sample Output 2
```
No
```

Explanation
In Sample 1, [7, 5, 4, 7] is not it. (10, 2, 4, 7) sums to 23. So Yes.
problems.hint: Sort the array. Use two nested loops for the first two elements, and then use the two-pointer technique for the remaining two elements. O(N^3).
problems.explanation:
Sorted Two-Pointer O(N^3) solution.

Step-by-step:
1. Sort the array.
2. Iterate `i` from 0 to N-4:
   - Iterate `j` from `i+1` to N-3:
     - Let `target = K - arr[i] - arr[j]`.
     - Initialize `left = j + 1`, `right = N - 1`.
     - While `left < right`:
       - `sum = arr[left] + arr[right]`.
       - If `sum == target`, return "Yes".
       - If `sum < target`, `left++`.
       - Else `right--`.
3. Return "No".

Trace Sample 1: Sorted [2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 10], K=23
- i=0 (2), j=1 (3), target=18. left=2 (4), right=5 (10). sum=14 < 18.
- i=0 (2), j=2 (4), target=17. left=3 (5), right=5 (10). sum=15 < 17.
- i=0 (2), j=3 (5), target=16. left=4 (7), right=5 (10). sum=17 > 16.
Result: Some triplet will eventually match. (2, 4, 7, 10) = 23.

problems.title: Trapping Rain Water
problems.description:
Given N non-negative integers representing an elevation map where the width of each bar is 1, compute how much water it can trap after raining.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the total amount of trapped water.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 2 * 10^4
• 0 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^5

Sample Input 1
```
12
0 1 0 2 1 0 1 3 2 1 2 1
```

Sample Output 1
```
6
```

Sample Input 2
```
6
4 2 0 3 2 5
```

Sample Output 2
```
9
```

Explanation
Sample 1: Elevation map [0,1,0,2,1,0,1,3,2,1,2,1] traps 6 units of water.
problems.hint: For each bar, water trapped = min(leftMax, rightMax) - height[i]. Use two pointers to calculate this efficiently in O(N).
problems.explanation:
Two-pointer O(N) solution.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `left = 0`, `right = N-1`, `leftMax = 0`, `rightMax = 0`, `res = 0`.
2. While `left <= right`:
   - If `height[left] <= height[right]`:
     - If `height[left] >= leftMax`, update `leftMax = height[left]`.
     - Else, `res += leftMax - height[left]`.
     - `left++`.
   - Else:
     - If `height[right] >= rightMax`, update `rightMax = height[right]`.
     - Else, `res += rightMax - height[right]`.
     - `right--`.
3. Return `res`.

Trace Sample 2 [4, 2, 0, 3, 2, 5]:
- l=0(4), r=5(5). lMax=4, l=1
- l=1(2), r=5(5). res += 4-2=2. l=2
- l=2(0), r=5(5). res += 4-0=4. l=3
- l=3(3), r=5(5). res += 4-3=1. l=4
- l=4(2), r=5(5). res += 4-2=2. l=5
Total res = 2+4+1+2 = 9.

problems.title: Merge Overlapping Intervals
problems.description:
Read N intervals [start, end]. Merge all overlapping intervals and print the resulting intervals sorted by start time.

Input Format
```
N
s1 e1
s2 e2
...
sN eN
```

Output Format
Print merged intervals, each as "start end" on a new line.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 5000
• 0 ≤ start ≤ end ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
4
1 3
2 6
8 10
15 18
```

Sample Output 1
```
1 6
8 10
15 18
```

Sample Input 2
```
2
1 4
4 5
```

Sample Output 2
```
1 5
```

Explanation
Intervals [1,3] and [2,6] overlap, so merge to [1,6].
problems.hint: Sort the intervals based on the start time. Then iterate and merge an interval with the previous one if it overlaps.
problems.explanation:
Sort and Merge O(N log N).

Step-by-step:
1. Sort the list of intervals by their start times.
2. Initialize `merged` list with the first interval.
3. For each subsequent interval:
   - If it overlaps with the last interval in `merged` (current.start <= last.end):
     - `merged.last.end = max(merged.last.end, current.end)`.
   - Else, add it to `merged`.
4. Print `merged` intervals.

Trace Sample 1: [[1,3], [2,6], [8,10], [15,18]]
- [2,6] overlaps with [1,3]? Yes (2 <= 3). Merge to [1, 6].
- [8,10] overlaps with [1,6]? No (8 > 6). Add [8,10].
- [15,18] overlaps with [8,10]? No. Add [15,18].
Result: 1 6, 8 10, 15 18

problems.title: Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers representing stock prices on different days. You are allowed to complete at most one transaction (buy and sell). Print the maximum profit you can achieve. If no profit is possible, print 0.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the maximum profit.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5
• 0 ≤ a[i] ≤ 1000

Sample Input 1
```
6
7 1 5 3 6 4
```

Sample Output 1
```
5
```

Sample Input 2
```
5
7 6 4 3 1
```

Sample Output 2
```
0
```

Explanation
Sample 1: Buy on day 2 (price 1) and sell on day 5 (price 6). Profit = 6 - 1 = 5.
Sample 2: Prices only go down, so no profit possible.
problems.hint: Keep track of the minimum price seen so far. For each daily price, calculate the profit if you sold that day, and record the maximum profit.
problems.explanation:
One-pass greedy approach O(N).

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `minPrice = infinity`, `maxProfit = 0`.
2. Iterate through each price `p` in the array:
   - `minPrice = min(minPrice, p)`.
   - `profit = p - minPrice`.
   - `maxProfit = max(maxProfit, profit)`.
3. Return `maxProfit`.

Trace [7, 1, 5, 3, 6, 4]:
- 7: min=7, profit=0, max=0
- 1: min=1, profit=0, max=0
- 5: min=1, profit=4, max=4
- 3: min=1, profit=2, max=4
- 6: min=1, profit=5, max=5
- 4: min=1, profit=3, max=5
Result: 5

problems.title: Rearrange Array Alternatingly
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers containing both positive and negative numbers. Rearrange them such that positive and negative numbers are at alternating positions, starting with a positive number. If there are extra elements of either sign, append them at the end. Order of appearance of same-signed elements must be maintained.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print space-separated rearranged integers.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 2000
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
1 2 3 -4 -1 4
```

Sample Output 1
```
1 -4 2 -1 3 4
```

Sample Input 2
```
4
-1 -2 -3 4
```

Sample Output 2
```
4 -1 -2 -3
```

Explanation
In Sample 1, Pos: [1,2,3,4], Neg: [-4,-1]. Alternating: 1, -4, 2, -1. Remaining positives: 3, 4.
problems.hint: Create two separate lists for positive and negative numbers. Then interleave them in the result array.
problems.explanation:
Separation and Interleaving logic.

Step-by-step:
1. Split elements into `pos` and `neg` lists (preserving order).
2. Initialize `i = 0`, `j = 0`.
3. While both lists have elements:
   - Append `pos[i++]` then `neg[j++]` to result.
4. Append remaining elements from either `pos` or `neg` to result.
5. Print result.

Trace Sample 1 [1, 2, 3, -4, -1, 4]:
pos = [1, 2, 3, 4], neg = [-4, -1]
Merge: 1, -4, 2, -1, 3, 4
Result: 1 -4 2 -1 3 4

problems.title: Maximize Sum of A[i]*i
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. You can rotate the array any number of times. Find the maximum value of the sum S = ∑(i * arr[i]) for all i from 0 to N-1 among all possible rotations.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the maximum sum.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 2 * 10^4
• 0 ≤ a[i] ≤ 1000

Sample Input 1
```
4
8 3 1 2
```

Sample Output 1
```
29
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
1 2 3
```

Sample Output 2
```
8
```

Explanation
Sample 1 [8, 3, 1, 2]:
- 0*8 + 1*3 + 2*1 + 3*2 = 11
- 1 rotation [2, 8, 3, 1]: 0*2 + 1*8 + 2*3 + 3*1 = 17
- 2 rotations [1, 2, 8, 3]: 0*1 + 1*2 + 2*8 + 3*3 = 27
- 3 rotations [3, 1, 2, 8]: 0*3 + 1*1 + 2*2 + 3*8 = 29. (Max)
problems.hint: Let S_k be the sum after k rotations. S_{k+1} = S_k + ArraySum - N * arr[N-1-k]. This allows calculating all rotation sums in O(N).
problems.explanation:
O(N) recurrence relation approach.

Step-by-step:
1. Calculate `arrSum = sum(arr)`.
2. Calculate initial sum `S0 = sum(i * arr[i])`.
3. Iterate `k` from 1 to N-1:
   - `Sk = Sk-1 + arrSum - N * arr[N-k]`.
   - Update `maxSum = max(maxSum, Sk)`.
4. Return `maxSum`.

Trace Sample 1 [8, 3, 1, 2]:
- arrSum = 14, S0 = 11
- k=1: S1 = 11 + 14 - 4*2 = 17
- k=2: S2 = 17 + 14 - 4*1 = 27
- k=3: S3 = 27 + 14 - 4*3 = 29
Result: 29

problems.title: Smallest Missing Positive Number
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Find the smallest positive integer (greater than 0) that is missing from the array.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the smallest missing positive number.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 2 * 10^4
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
1 2 0 -10 -20
```

Sample Output 1
```
3
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
3 4 -1 1
```

Sample Output 2
```
2
```

Explanation
Sample 1: [1, 2] present. Smallest positive missing is 3.
Sample 2: [1, 3, 4] present. Smallest positive missing is 2.
problems.hint: Try to place each number X at its correct position `arr[X-1]`. After one pass, the first index `i` where `arr[i] != i+1` gives the missing number `i+1`.
problems.explanation:
In-place cycle sort logic O(N) time, O(1) space.

Step-by-step:
1. Iterate through array:
   - While `arr[i]` is in range [1, N] and `arr[i] != arr[arr[i]-1]`:
     - Swap `arr[i]` with `arr[arr[i]-1]`.
2. Iterate through array again:
   - The first index `i` where `arr[i] != i + 1` is the result: `i + 1`.
3. If all are correct, return `N + 1`.

Trace [3, 4, -1, 1]:
- i=0: val 3. Swap with arr[2]: [-1, 4, 3, 1]
- i=0: val -1. Skip.
- i=1: val 4. Swap with arr[3]: [-1, 1, 3, 4]
- i=1: val 1. Swap with arr[0]: [1, -1, 3, 4]
- i=1: val -1. Skip.
- i=2, 3: Skip (correct pos).
Final: [1, -1, 3, 4]. Index 1 has -1. Result = 2.

problems.title: Longest Consecutive Sequence
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Find the length of the longest consecutive elements sequence in the array. The sequence can be in any order in the array.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the length of the sequence.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 2 * 10^4
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
6
100 4 200 1 3 2
```

Sample Output 1
```
4
```

Sample Input 2
```
10
0 3 7 2 5 8 4 6 0 1
```

Sample Output 2
```
9
```

Explanation
Sample 1: Longest consecutive sequence is [1, 2, 3, 4]. Length 4.
Sample 2: sequence [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]. Length 9.
problems.hint: Put all elements in a hash set. For each element X, if X-1 is not in the set, start counting consecutive integers X, X+1, X+2... and update max length.
problems.explanation:
Set-based approach for O(N) time.

Step-by-step:
1. Insert all elements into a hash set.
2. Iterate through each number `x` in the set:
   - Check if `x - 1` exists in the set.
   - If NO (it's the start of a sequence):
     - `currentNum = x`, `currentStreak = 1`.
     - While `currentNum + 1` exists in set:
       - `currentNum++`, `currentStreak++`.
     - `maxStreak = max(maxStreak, currentStreak)`.
3. Return `maxStreak`.

Trace [100, 4, 200, 1, 3, 2]:
- 100: 99 not in set. streak=1. 101 not in set. max=1
- 4: 3 is in set. skip.
- 200: 199 not in set. streak=1. max=1
- 1: 0 not in set. streak=1. 2 in set, 3 in set, 4 in set. max=4.
Result: 4

problems.title: Sliding Window Maximum
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers and a window size K. For each sliding window of size K (moving from left to right), find the maximum element and print all such maximums space-separated.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
K
```

Output Format
Print space-separated maximums for each of the N-K+1 windows.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 2 * 10^4
• 1 ≤ K ≤ N
• −10^4 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^4

Sample Input 1
```
8
1 3 -1 -3 5 3 6 7
3
```

Sample Output 1
```
3 3 5 5 6 7
```

Sample Input 2
```
1
5
1
```

Sample Output 2
```
5

Explanation
Window [1, 3, -1]: Max 3
Window [3, -1, -3]: Max 3
Window [-1, -3, 5]: Max 5
Window [-3, 5, 3]: Max 5
Window [5, 3, 6]: Max 6
Window [3, 6, 7]: Max 7
problems.hint: Use a deque (double-ended queue) to store indices of elements in the current window. Maintain the deque such that elements are in decreasing order of their values.
problems.explanation:
Deque-based O(N) solution.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize a deque `dq` to store indices.
2. Iterate through array at index `i`:
   - Remove indices from front if they are out of the window (`dq[0] <= i - K`).
   - Remove indices from back if `arr[dq.back()] <= arr[i]` (elements smaller than current are useless).
   - Add `i` to back.
   - If `i >= K-1`, print `arr[dq.front()]`.

Trace Sample 1 [1, 3, -1, -3, 5, 3, 6, 7], K=3:
- i=0: dq=[0]
- i=1: 1 > 0(val 1), pop. dq=[1]
- i=2: -1 < 1(val 3), dq=[1, 2]. res=[3]
- i=3: -3 < 2(val -1), dq=[1, 2, 3]. res=[3, 3]
- i=4: 5 > 3(-3), 5 > 2(-1), 5 > 1(3). pop all. dq=[4]. res=[3, 3, 5]
...

problems.title: Longest Subarray with Equal 0s and 1s
problems.description:
Read a binary array of N integers (containing only 0s and 1s). Find the length of the longest continuous subarray that contains an equal number of 0s and 1s. Print the length.

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print the maximum length.

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 2 * 10^4
• a[i] ∈ {0, 1}

Sample Input 1
```
7
1 0 1 1 1 0 0
```

Sample Output 1
```
6
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
1 1 1
```

Sample Output 2
```
0
```

Explanation
Sample 1: Subarray from index 1 to 6 [0, 1, 1, 1, 0, 0] has three 0s and three 1s. Length 6.
problems.hint: Replace all 0s in the array with -1. Now the problem reduces to finding the longest subarray with sum 0.
problems.explanation:
Hashing and Prefix Sum reduction O(N).

Step-by-step:
1. Replace all 0s with -1.
2. Initialize `sum = 0`, `maxLen = 0`, and a map `map = {0: -1}`.
3. Iterate through array at index `i`:
   - `sum += arr[i]`.
   - If `sum` is in `map`:
     - `maxLen = max(maxLen, i - map[sum])`.
   - Else:
     - `map[sum] = i`.
4. Return `maxLen`.

Trace [1, 0, 1, 1, 1, 0, 0]:
Modified: [1, -1, 1, 1, 1, -1, -1]
- i=0, pSum=1. map={0:-1, 1:0}
- i=1, pSum=0. 0 in map? Yes. len=1-(-1)=2. max=2.
- i=2, pSum=1. 1 in map? Yes. len=2-0 = 2. max=2.
- i=3, pSum=2. map={..., 2:3}
- i=4, pSum=3. map={..., 3:4}
- i=5, pSum=2. 2 in map? Yes. len=5-3 = 2. max=2.
- i=6, pSum=1. 1 in map? Yes. len=6-0 = 6. max=6.
Result: 6

problems.title: Subarray with Sum 0
problems.description:
Read an array of N integers. Determine if there exists a continuous subarray whose elements sum up to exactly 0. Print "Yes" if found, otherwise "No".

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print "Yes" or "No".

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 2 * 10^4
• −10^6 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^6

Sample Input 1
```
5
4 2 -3 1 6
```

Sample Output 1
```
Yes
```

Sample Input 2
```
3
1 2 3
```

Sample Output 2
```
No
```

Explanation
In [4, 2, -3, 1, 6], subarray [2, -3, 1] sums to 0. So Yes.
problems.hint: Use a hash set to store prefix sums. If the current prefix sum is 0 or it has been seen before, a subarray with sum 0 exists.
problems.explanation:
Prefix Sum + Hashing O(N) solution.

Step-by-step:
1. Initialize `prefixSum = 0` and an empty set `seen`.
2. Iterate through array:
   - `prefixSum += arr[i]`.
   - If `prefixSum == 0` or `prefixSum` is in `seen`, return "Yes".
   - Add `prefixSum` to `seen`.
3. Return "No".

Trace [4, 2, -3, 1, 6]:
- val=4: pSum=4. seen={4}
- val=2: pSum=6. seen={4, 6}
- val=-3: pSum=3. seen={4, 6, 3}
- val=1: pSum=4. 4 is in `seen`! MATCH.
Result: Yes

problems.title: Jump Game
problems.description:
Read an array of N non-negative integers. Each element represents your maximum jump length at that position. Starting at the first index, determine if you are able to reach the last index. Print "Yes" or "No".

Input Format
```
N
a1 a2 ... aN
```

Output Format
Print "Yes" or "No".

Constraints
• 1 ≤ N ≤ 2 * 10^4
• 0 ≤ a[i] ≤ 10^5

Sample Input 1
```
5
2 3 1 1 4
```

Sample Output 1
```
Yes
```

Sample Input 2
```
5
3 2 1 0 4
```

Sample Output 2
```
No
```
